								After playing for a short while, I sat down in my living room grinning from ear to ear, my wife asked me how US2 was, I said "Oh man, I've never felt so close to feeling like an actual god"She replies "Not even when we are having sex?"I said "Would you describe us having sex as...? a Nuclear explosion?""Yes" she replied.I paused, looked up at her and said "Yeah, I just threw Suns at each other"Words cannot describe this experience, you just have to try it.Although as some have said, not all features work in VR and the controls are a bit clunky.WARNING: This game runs fairly easy until it gets busy, once things start getting full and busy your PC might tank and lock up causing you to have to End Process, but that was expected.My specs:i7 6700k16GB RAMR9 390 Nitro 8GBSSD drive.

								After playing for a short while, I sat down in my living room grinning from ear to ear, my wife asked me how US2 was, I said "Oh man, I've never felt so close to feeling like an actual god"She replies "Not even when we are having sex?"I said "Would you describe us having sex as...? a Nuclear explosion?""Yes" she replied.I paused, looked up at her and said "Yeah, I just threw Suns at each other"Words cannot describe this experience, you just have to try it.Although as some have said, not all features work in VR and the controls are a bit clunky.WARNING: This game runs fairly easy until it gets busy, once things start getting full and busy your PC might tank and lock up causing you to have to End Process, but that was expected.My specs:i7 6700k16GB RAMR9 390 Nitro 8GBSSD drive.

Or You Can Load The Solar System And Place Black Holes Everywhere.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Absolutely fascinating and a fantastic educational tool for kids.This is a program EVERY science school in the country should have access to.It is really good that you can change things to see different energy releases etc, really fascinating to watch, and if you have a beefy PC like I do, its just sickly awesome.I totally recommend everyone buy this and try this, no you wont get hundreds of playing hours out of it unless your an astrologist with OCD issues, but what you do get is a facinating look at the universe/solar system from a completely different perspective.Watch it on a 71 inch super high def screen.Its like taking the NASA supercomputer and slapping it in your lounge !Cheap and fun and great for teaching kids how things work off our planet, buy it.

content:
Posted: April 9
Early Access Review
								Might have bought this as a knee jerk decision. "Ooooo physics, I want it!"Unfortunately I was a little bummed out with what I could do in this game. After checking out every scenario that came with the game there was a disappointing moment when I realized I didn't want to just fling stuff at Earth and watch the same Micheal Bay movie each time.Adding mass to planets was fun. Turning Jupiter into a star was super cool. Watching moons corkscrew around an orbiting planet was fascinating.Its not that I didn't enjoy this game at all, but I was just a little blind sided by the price considering how little there was to do. Looks pretty though. Maybe its more of a UniverseScreensaver.Will re-review as this game is early access! Maybe I will learn to love it.6/10 would watch Julian moons orbit Jupiter again

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I came to the realisation that Pluto was mad because he was downgraded from a planet to basically a non-existent rock. Pluto wanted revenge.I increased Plutos mass to the size of Jupiter. Pluto grew suddenly.It wasn't enough. I increased Plutos surface tempreture to 3000c. I again, increased his mass, to the mass of the sun. Pluto glowed an angry red, whilst throwing off the orbit of nearby planets. It still wasn't enough.I decided to completely let loose, and I increased Plutos mass to 1000 the times of the sun. Not-so-little Pluto grew massive, consuming everything in his path, and completely ruining the orbits of other planets. Pluto stared at the sun. Pluto drifted towards the sun, in a red ball of anger. Pluto hit the sun, and then...Silence.Suddenly, the sun went supernova, and consumed the entire solar system. All at the hands of little Pluto. 11\10 would destroy our solar system again

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								really like this series, i played Universe Sandbox 1 alot and this is huge improvment on the pervious sandbox. base line: its just fun to explore and mess with the solar system and the star charts, like a road map for the universe/ sol system that you can mess up and even destroy with a black hole. the detail to the planets is nice and the climate controls are crazy, such as removing all the water from a planet or raising the tempature and watching the ice caps melt. there are even a few pop culture refrences such as the phantom zone and the monolith from 2001. random thought: its very informative about the galaxy i feel that if i were to get lost in the sol system i could look at some star charts and get back. closing: welp all in all it just fun. would buy the 3rd one. 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								PROs:- This games need to exist- There is not a single objetive or points. Its a pure sandbox- Lots of pre-made simulations- Beautiful. Great sense of scale. Slow music: Perfecto to unwindCONs- Even tho is very enjoyable in its current state, this is far from finished- Glitchy: planets disappearing for no reason, tutorial text covering the options, game refuses to close...- Tutorials are very limited. There are tons of variables on this game. Educational value is very low right now- No community simulations- No current "known universe" simulation available where you can zoom in and out. At least I didnt find it- Explosions are horrible: the planets either merge in a perfect brand new sphere or create a crater that is nothing but a 3d model of a crater on the spot of the collision. This means you cant destroy a planet little by little and that collisions dont "stack"- Time only moves forward. No rewind button- They push you constantly to rate the game. I know this is effective in increasing the number of reviews, but is not okay in my book- Planet details when you zoom in is not bad, but is less that I would like

content:
Posted: February 13
Early Access Review
								I loved this game. Emphasis on the past tense. I was excited to play it and when I was able to it was a ton of fun. But now there's an issue where the initial load screen will pop up and at the bottom it'll read "starting the sandbox" and then it'll just stop. No error message. It'll just sit there like that until I click and windows says it's not responding. I don't know if it's because my computer is a piece of crap or what but I looked up solutions and tried most and nothing worked. I don't know what to do now but just warn others that this can happen by writing a review. I bought and now can't play this game. I really hope that this issue is eventually fixed because I want to recommend this to everyone who loves space and physics and such but when there is an issue like this that literally makes the game unplayable I just can't recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox 2 is a game where you mess around with the universe. It mainly focuses on solar systems and you can make your own and such using random presets. The game is in early access and hopefully the devs will work on it over the next several months. Should you buy this game?I loved to watch videos of this game but was put off it by one particular comment. "The game gets boring quickly." I got the game 4 months later as one of my family members said I could buy something as long as it is either educational or physical.The game was not boring. It was incredibly fun and time flies when I play it. The only issue I have is it's a game you play before you go to work/bed. Game sessions are usually over 1 hour for me but that is due to me owning the game for a small time. So it all comes down to this...Buy this game if you love space, explosions, astronomy or just science in general. Avoid if you are looking for a big game with lots of content you can binge on. Do pick this game up sometime though as it is a huge improvement from the first game (which I hated).I don't like to give anything a score as scores are translated differently. I will however give this game one word that I think it deserves. Success.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox is a beautiful game which offers numerous simulations of things like our solar system, black holes, and binary pulsars. However, the simulations are (relatively) small scale, as in, you can't navigate our known universe. For example, I expected to be able to zoom out from the solar system and see celestial bodies which surround ours in the Milky Way, then zoom out even further to see what's around the Milky Way. As of now, this isn't possible, though it may be added since the game is in open alpha.Unfortunately, in its present state, this isn't much of a "universe" sandbox as it is just a space sandbox. Very disappointed!

content:
Posted: February 7
Early Access Review
								A glorified n-body physics simulator that's as dull as dishwater and pointless.It's interesting for a few minutes, until you start noticing the limitations of the "simulation".Smash Earth with the moon? It's okay--it'll cool back down to clement temperatues a year after turning into a molten ball of fire, and all the continents will still be in place--even with city lights in the night time!Change Jupiter's tilt somehow? Its cloud system will not change or shift with the new tilt.So you're basically buying a simulator where the planets are just textured balls. There's some crude climate simulation for Earth that is just wrong--even with 2C over current global temperatures, we have Europe looking like it did 10,000 years ago during the last Ice Age.The collisions are vaguely entertaining for a while, until you notice that the larger colliding body essentially never changes--it just gets more massive with the same textures remaining.And to add to my bitterness, a refund was refused--so screw you too, Valve. Way to encourage software piracy.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								-The solar simulation is lacking, a star will always be 100% hydrogen. Even if it has a thousand years until supernova, even if it is already a stellar remnant - neither a neutron star nor a white dwarf is 100% hydrogen.-There are only 6 "elements", or rather things bodies can consist of: hydrogen, water, silicate, iron, organic and dark matter.-Any object can easily be accelerated above light speed.-Any planet or star can rotate as fast as it wants, they never break apart-There is no mass transfer in a binary star system. Red giant and a white dwarf, which are just way too close? No mass transfer, no accretion disk, nothing.-The collision system is glitchy.Right now, these are the reasons why I'm somewhat disappointed in this.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
Early Access Review
THIS IS NOT A GAMEIn the strictest sense, this is not a game.  It is a toy, something for you to sit down with for a few hours and just see what it is like to destroy Earth, or the Sun, or the Milky Way.This is not something that would appeal to many people.  You have to be extremely interested in astrophysics to even want to buy this title, and those that are educated in astrophysics, you start to notice some issues with this right away such as the lack of space-time distortion near massive objects such as black holes or super-massive stars.  This game is very rhudementary at the simulation of basic physics and does not apply any theorethical rules that we have found to be true in the past decade which is disappointing.Orbits are innacurate, showing loss of velocity on each revolution just by having an abnormal or eliptical orbit.  While unstable orbits can maraculiously become stable (there is a reason they're called unstable, because there is a collision trajectory). This is not true to life and violates the laws of thermal dynamics. The show stopper, was having objects that can move as fast as the speed of light.  The current school of thought says that the more massive an object is, the expodentially harder it is to achieve speeds remotely close to the speed of light.  In essence, the fatter you are, the harder it is to run fast.  The universe has the same laws, which are violated in this "toy".Again, this is a TOY, not even a simulator, if this was listed on steam as such I would have gave it a glowing recommendation.  However, this is no game, and is decietful to market it as such because there is no playing field, no objective, no goal.  It is a sandbox with sand -- which is a toy, again, not a game.

number of helpful: 3 of 17 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								**I'm going to stress that this is a review for the current Alpha of this "game" (toy?). I fully expect to change my review to positive when it releases.**Right now, its fairly limited. Setting up your own systems is much harder than it should be -for me at least- and usually ends in lots of explosions, getting objects where you want them just isn't very intuitive.I wouldn't say the game runs poorly, but it could run a lot better. However, After playing it again recently, I definitely noticed improvement, so I imagine the game will run quite smoothly by release.The number of objects you get to play around with feels a bit lackluster, but that should also be improved. They are also planning to add Steam Workshop integration, which would be more than enough.The game does let you edit a metric ton of attributes for every object in real time, as well as gravity and other such things, which is pretty sweet. If you want to run a simulation with 1,000x normal gravity and an Earth the size of 1,000,000,000 suns, you can do that.In its current state, I wouldn't recommend this unless you're really into astronomy, or just have a thing for blowing up planets. But it definitely has potential to be great later on. I definitely expect to come back to this one later on.(If you like my reviews, I'm posting them all on this hideous Wordpress site now! https://probablysanny.wordpress.com/)

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Slightly disappointed. Seems to me that the main focus is for ramming planets into other planets (or stars, moons, asteroids, etc.) I watched the Jupiter/Jupiter collision. One is stationary one comes in from the left and rams into the other. Nice graphics. The final object is the same size and for some reason is moving to the left. (???) That doesn't seem right.  I don't see any way to set up a solar system with custom orbits. Sure, I made one system, but all orbits were round and in the same plane. That's not very natural. I don't see how to customize that. I went right through all the tutorials. I can make a pulsar! Ooh. big deal. I see a computer graphic of a magnetized white dwarf. Is that what they really look like? Maybe a bit.I'm quite an astronomy fanatic, but I don't feel I got $30 worth. Of course, it is an early access release and so it could still get better yet. Let's hope it gets a lot better. I don't understand all these thumbs up recommendations, seriously.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really wanted to enjoy this simulation.  But it's severely lacking as is.  Here are my gripes:#1- Each simulation type is independent of the other.  I was expecting all worlds to have environmental simulations enabled, but they don't.  Only specially designed prefabs (earth and mars I think are only ones?) have the environmental simulation enabled.  There are other simulation setups, but they seem too pigeonholed to really allow for true sandbox tinkering.#2- It seems like the only interesting things I do are collisions and design some cool orbits I guess.  The level of simulation detail in other areas is far too little to make it fun to me.#3- Why doesn't the matter projectile thingy add to a planet's makeup and mass?  Atmosphere mechanics are awful.  I was expecting to be able to add gasses or water to a planet and have it establish an atmosphere, or maybe it wasn't big enough to hold an atmosphere?  All cloud cover looks the same as earths, there is no attempt to model a planets atmosphere, and there is absolutely no detail paid to the amazing amount of atmospheric complexity of gas giants.(these two below are minor gripes)#4- The simulation including all moons (or even our own moon) is a bit hidden, and I can't find a pre-built simulation including all the defined solar system objects.#5- Can't you come up with some way to model multiple star systems realistically?  Would be cool if I can hurl one star system at another and see the results  Maybe pause and group multiple stable(ish) objects together as one mass data point at very far zoom distances so that you can actually build a few systems.#6- The interface needs lots of work.  If I have hundreds of objects on screen, why not (by default) just display the most important trails and orbits at extreme zooms?  Like if I'm looking at the solar system, only the major planets should be shown at max zoom, as I zoom in more, show me smaller and smaller objects or something?  Things get extremely cluttered.  Also, the pause on impact needs a threshold or something and maybe detect an impact a few minutes before it happens so that I can watch or intervene on the things I'm actually interested in.If you like to watch planets collide for hours with predictable identical results every time, you might get enjoyment out of this.  The only reason I personally didn't ask for return from the dev is that it's a very cool project and I'm hoping I can come back to it in another couple years and it is more the fully featured simulation I was hoping for originally.  Also, the devs care deeply for this game which is great news!

Posted: November 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I can't create a functional solar system yet but I can sure figure out a way to f**k it up by just clicking on things. Terrorism simulator 2015. 9/11 would be a universal terrorist again.Pros-You can blow planets up with ease, no need for silly nukes, warframes, or deathstars.-Cool presets which usually result in some sort of destruction, or can be modified to cause it with minimal effort.-See how many times you can f**k over the Earth and realize how fragile it is so you can't sleep at night.-Shouting ALLAHU AKBAR when blowing up the Earth is satisfying.-Black holes-Pretty colors when things blow up.-Did I mention destroying things.Cons-Can get a bit laggy at times (but thats probably just me putting an excessive amount of space things for no reason and my laptop cant handle it)-Get mad at the universe or god or whatever you want to believe in because you can't create a perfect solar system unless you use presets or are in fact god.-Makes you fear for your very existance.-A few bugs here and there as with any game but nothing gamebreaking, barely notice them.Overall I would definatly give this game a 10/10 at its current state. Get it if you like to see stuff in the universe blowing up.

Posted: November 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amongst the best examples of merging accurate simulations with beautiful interfaces. A great example of how well everything works is to drop the timescale to realtime, place a still moon in the path of the earth, and watch as the atmosphere burns away, followed by the seas, followed by the earth becoming a molten ball. You can even graph properties of earth as compared with other planetary bodies to see how close this gets earth to the temperature of the sun.

Posted: November 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is beautiful. Absolutely stunning. It has great physics and calming music. Great for those interested in astronomy. I havent even played this game for an hour yet, and I have already fallen in love. It doesn't ask for much on your computer, and its graphics are beautiful. It abides to the laws of physics, so you wont be seeing planets randomly shoot into the skies at speeds faster than that of light, therefor you are able to control your craetions without everything exploding instantly. Its easy to get used to, and the tutorial gives you a good explanation of the game. If you're not great at creating, you can play around with the pre-made simulations. Overall, I would definitely recommend this game. 10/10

Early Access Review
								 For this to be an early access game, and only in it's Alpha stage I belive this is a great game; even if it were fully released in this state! The game doesn't simuate life growing on a planet or reletiviy since it's in Alpha, but instead has supernovas! And climate changes, and black holes, and even tidal heating!This game allows you to do so much tweaking to the point where you'll sit and ask your self. "This is only in Alpha?!" Well yes it is, and I can hardly wait to see it's future updates to see what they add and fix! If you at all like space or science or anything like that, you'll probably love this game!This game has so much detail to it, and is down right beautiful! It highly recommend you look into it. It is for sure worth your time!

Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just bought it, played it for a bit. Gotta say it is a sweet buy, I just had a trippy and eye-opening experience about how space works. Plus I just browsed the community hub, and these developers clearly care about what the user thinks. Some cool stuff I noticed:-Super well polished, menu is clear and stylish.-Cool music, instils a sense of wonder and awe.-Sound effects! Subtle, but appreciated. Zoom into a star while wearing headphones and there is this cool eerie and powerful sounding rumble.-I zoomed around space, found an asteroid way beyond plutos orbit. Googed it, found it was real. Read wikipedia articles about it. Set its mass to be equivalent to the sun.What I am saying is, if you are interested in space and wanna mess around in a simulation of the universe where you have godlike powers over time and matter and 25 bucks doesn't sound like too much to drop for those powers than buy it!

Posted: October 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I definitely recommend picking up this game. I got it a while back when it was in Alpha 10 or so, and the devs have been quite good at adding new content with fairly regular updates. I can't wait to see what the full release will look like. Stunning graphics and surprisingly well optimised. I've seen some reviews complaining about the lack of content. Although there isn't an overwhelming amount of content, if you use your imagination, you can create some quite spectacular sims. You want to grow a tiny rock to the size of a galaxy and destroy huge solar systems? You can do it. You want to blow up the sun? You can do it. You want to endlessly bombard Earth with meteorites? You can do it. You want to recreate the extinction of the dinosaurs? You can also do it. The fun is nearly endless with this game.

Posted: December 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a science and science fiction enthusiast, I highly recommend this simulation program/game that lets us play around and discover. It lets us answer our "What would happen if...?" questions, see the different scenarios we can create and how they turn out.Keep in mind, every day, we are still learning and our understanding of the universe around us changes over time. As well as the fact this game is in early access. It is by far finished and there are plenty of bugs and glitches we, the community, can help discover and report to the developers so that they may improve and turn this gem into a real beauty.The controls can be a little confusing at first, the tutorials are good but could use a little bit or work (or perhaps more tutorials!) but take your time to explore each function, sometimes there are more options than is immediately apparent.Overall I am happy with this program and I hope it gets the attention and success it deserves.

Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								My first impression after 43 minutes of exploring this Sandbox:If you like Space(Or planning to be future Physicst as me) - IT IS A MUST. It's really mindbuggling & really opening your horizons about what looks like small dot in the sky. You can adjust anything and I even made huge basketball ball(Larger than earth) to see what's happening if it collides Earth. It's a great way to get your spirit up and your imagination a great deal of fun. You have so many planets, collison courses and so on you can do. It's a great way to learn about the universe. You can really adjust almost important things about planets & physics engine not bad at all.The turtorial is really simple, very fluid and easy to comprehend.The downsize of the game that sometimes it doesn't look as it's in real life. Especially the explosions & how planets/stars really look in life. I think many properties are missing when it comes to this. The Sun's explosion is fantastic, close to be real and also BEAUTIFUL thing ever!There is so many things they should add, even from Star Wars(Death Star) that would really make it awesome.  Last thing on my mind, the 3D graphic is quite simple, nothing special. It's a good thing if you have bad computer. You'll have problems only with too many objects or explosions at once(Getting close to them too).All in all - I LOVE SPACE - AWESOME!

Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox is one of the best simulation games I've played. Being able to mess around with the universe or simply create a solar system and see how it turns out in millions of years is great fun and also a learning experience. I'll be especially excited when the possible simulation of life is added, and I hope that when it happens there will be more options for the planets meant to carry it. I have more to experiment with of course, but I definitely am going to follow this game's development. I don't dislike much about this game, and for still being in development it's a fantastic start. Anything I could critique about creativity limits will undoubtedly be addressed in the future (Like the creation of life on planets).I'd recommend this game to anyone who is curious about the universe and how it works. Also for anyone just interested in messing around in space. It is definitely worth getting, and few people aren't interested in outer space, so it seems like a good fit for most.All in all, it's worth finding out about and looking at. I highly recommend this to anyone I know.

Posted: October 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is the game (simulator?) I have always DREAMED of having. From nudging two pool balls together in LEO to crashing two galaxies together and watching them get torn apart star by star, the game performs well and satisfies.My only suggestion:Allow us to filter celestial objects in name, mass, radius order etc...But if you've played the first and even enjoyed it somewhat, this will quench your thirst. The UI is different in a good way, yet still very similar to the first, so there shouldn't be much confusion there.Infact, I'm struggling to find a downside to this game, in my honest opinion, it has done nothing but improve since the first.I'm a huge Elite and EVE Online fan, and this game gives me what those games can't. Those games allow me to slowly cruise around the galaxy, oggle at the stars as I whizz past.This game allows me to take those stars and smash them together at half the speed of light.11/10 would definitely recommend. (Even if space doesn't exite you as much as it does me)

Posted: October 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								There aren't enough synonyms for beautiful, because this simulation is all of them plus more. My cat was sitting next to me, and when he watched this, he turned into a fullgrown griffin. I am awestruck by this. Please, please, please support the developers and purchase this title. If you are on the fence about it, get off that fence and come on over to the dark side. Or the light side. You choose, that's the beauty. Oh, you wanna make a pulsar? Cool. Then you want to feed earth to that pulsar? Cool. Then you wanna start throwing black holes around all willy nilly until everything is whirling around in an unstoppable whirlwind of antimatter and teapots? That's cool too. Don't let your dreams be dreams, just do it.

You have to do everything to make something happen. (can take a lot of time)

								Just bought it, played it for a bit. Gotta say it is a sweet buy, I just had a trippy and eye-opening experience about how space works. Plus I just browsed the community hub, and these developers clearly care about what the user thinks. Some cool stuff I noticed:-Super well polished, menu is clear and stylish.-Cool music, instils a sense of wonder and awe.-Sound effects! Subtle, but appreciated. Zoom into a star while wearing headphones and there is this cool eerie and powerful sounding rumble.-I zoomed around space, found an asteroid way beyond plutos orbit. Googed it, found it was real. Read wikipedia articles about it. Set its mass to be equivalent to the sun.What I am saying is, if you are interested in space and wanna mess around in a simulation of the universe where you have godlike powers over time and matter and 25 bucks doesn't sound like too much to drop for those powers than buy it!

Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Are you a nerd? Do you wonder how things would be different if Mars was closer to the Sun? Or what it would be like if the Earth had two moons? Have you ever wanted to make your own solar system just to see what would happen? Or maybe smash an asteroid into Venus? Or maybe see what happens when you throw a rogue planet into the solar system? You can do these things are more in Universe Sandbox^2. I found out about this quite game quite accidentally. I had played Space Engine before, and someone mentioned that I should try US^2 if I liked SE. While SE is more of a space-exploration game, US^2 is a sandbox - you can twiddle with settings to see how things change. I guess it's kind of like playing God. If you had that sense of wonder when you played Space Engine, you can get that here too. You can see how planets change over the scale of centuries and millenia when you mess with their climates. You can change Mars' climate so that it has water. The possibilities are endless.This is a great learning tool too, especially for children who are interested in astronomy.Even though it is only in alpha, US^2 is still amazing. If it's so good now, I can't even imagine how amazing the final product will be.

Though I wish they'd feature more exoplanet systems and have more collision setups. However these are just nitpicks. The actual problems have to do with psychics themselves for example if Jupiter and Neptune were moving toward each other at 12 km/s Jupiter would not just swallow Neptune whole leaving a giant crater.

Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's early access, I know, but totally worth the money.Pros: - Scale, holy ♥♥♥♥ing cow O.o from tiny asteroids to massive stars, everything goes, everything is   there. in its size. - Options, options and even more options!  - fully controllable planets and stars, from their rough elemental make up to climate, velocity or    rotation and axis. You're the boss now - Awesome scenarios come build in. a galaxy merger, our solar system in all detail O.o just sit and    follow Saturn and its moons for a while - Soundtrack, few tracks, but memorable and extremely fitting for the onscreen action or lack there of. - No sandbox without tools of destruction. play with the mass of a planet and create a blackhole,    ♥♥♥♥ up a star and see a supernova unfold. or just blow them up with your almighty finger of god :D - graphics, while nothing 'special', it manages to deliver a rather pleasant viewing experience.   and don't get me wrong, it will impress you, over and over againCons: - after the recent update there's nothing I can complain about :)Can't wait for it to be finished. But so far it's been one hell of a ride. and I'll tag along until the end

Posted: October 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								I definitely recommend picking up this game. I got it a while back when it was in Alpha 10 or so, and the devs have been quite good at adding new content with fairly regular updates. I can't wait to see what the full release will look like. Stunning graphics and surprisingly well optimised. I've seen some reviews complaining about the lack of content. Although there isn't an overwhelming amount of content, if you use your imagination, you can create some quite spectacular sims. You want to grow a tiny rock to the size of a galaxy and destroy huge solar systems? You can do it. You want to blow up the sun? You can do it. You want to endlessly bombard Earth with meteorites? You can do it. You want to recreate the extinction of the dinosaurs? You can also do it. The fun is nearly endless with this game.

Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just bought it, played it for a bit. Gotta say it is a sweet buy, I just had a trippy and eye-opening experience about how space works. Plus I just browsed the community hub, and these developers clearly care about what the user thinks. Some cool stuff I noticed:-Super well polished, menu is clear and stylish.-Cool music, instils a sense of wonder and awe.-Sound effects! Subtle, but appreciated. Zoom into a star while wearing headphones and there is this cool eerie and powerful sounding rumble.-I zoomed around space, found an asteroid way beyond plutos orbit. Googed it, found it was real. Read wikipedia articles about it. Set its mass to be equivalent to the sun.What I am saying is, if you are interested in space and wanna mess around in a simulation of the universe where you have godlike powers over time and matter and 25 bucks doesn't sound like too much to drop for those powers than buy it!

I highly recommend this simulator for anyone looking to learn a little bit about space, as well as play god with space. I really liked the first one, and I fell in love with the second one. Here are some reasons I fell in love:1) This title made me completely forget about the previous it was that fantastic of an improvement.2) The collisions are absolutely stunning.3) Fantastic development team.4) Real time physics sandbox.5) Graphically impressive6) Anything can be in slow motion, real time, or high speed. Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								My first impression after 43 minutes of exploring this Sandbox:If you like Space(Or planning to be future Physicst as me) - IT IS A MUST. It's really mindbuggling & really opening your horizons about what looks like small dot in the sky. You can adjust anything and I even made huge basketball ball(Larger than earth) to see what's happening if it collides Earth. It's a great way to get your spirit up and your imagination a great deal of fun. You have so many planets, collison courses and so on you can do. It's a great way to learn about the universe. You can really adjust almost important things about planets & physics engine not bad at all.The turtorial is really simple, very fluid and easy to comprehend.The downsize of the game that sometimes it doesn't look as it's in real life. Especially the explosions & how planets/stars really look in life. I think many properties are missing when it comes to this. The Sun's explosion is fantastic, close to be real and also BEAUTIFUL thing ever!There is so many things they should add, even from Star Wars(Death Star) that would really make it awesome.  Last thing on my mind, the 3D graphic is quite simple, nothing special. It's a good thing if you have bad computer. You'll have problems only with too many objects or explosions at once(Getting close to them too).All in all - I LOVE SPACE - AWESOME!

								This is the kind of game the late Carl Sagan would have had wet dreams about.  You don't even have to do anything in it. Posted: October 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is the game (simulator?) I have always DREAMED of having. From nudging two pool balls together in LEO to crashing two galaxies together and watching them get torn apart star by star, the game performs well and satisfies.My only suggestion:Allow us to filter celestial objects in name, mass, radius order etc...But if you've played the first and even enjoyed it somewhat, this will quench your thirst. The UI is different in a good way, yet still very similar to the first, so there shouldn't be much confusion there.Infact, I'm struggling to find a downside to this game, in my honest opinion, it has done nothing but improve since the first.I'm a huge Elite and EVE Online fan, and this game gives me what those games can't. Those games allow me to slowly cruise around the galaxy, oggle at the stars as I whizz past.This game allows me to take those stars and smash them together at half the speed of light.11/10 would definitely recommend. (Even if space doesn't exite you as much as it does me)

Posted: October 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								There aren't enough synonyms for beautiful, because this simulation is all of them plus more. My cat was sitting next to me, and when he watched this, he turned into a fullgrown griffin. I am awestruck by this. Please, please, please support the developers and purchase this title. If you are on the fence about it, get off that fence and come on over to the dark side. Or the light side. You choose, that's the beauty. Oh, you wanna make a pulsar? Cool. Then you want to feed earth to that pulsar? Cool. Then you wanna start throwing black holes around all willy nilly until everything is whirling around in an unstoppable whirlwind of antimatter and teapots? That's cool too. Don't let your dreams be dreams, just do it.

								Let me tell you something: If you have ever wanted to learn complicated scientific concepts while also being incredibly destructive, this game is for you. With this game, you can live out all of your sick, twisted fantasies about destroying the Earth and/or the solar system, as well as other things, like bowling balls. You can also use the bowling balls to destroy the Earth. The choice is yours to make. There's no better way to learn orbital physics. I give this game 1000 decimated planets/10.

Posted: October 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								A very beautiful "game", Universe Sandbox ² is a pleasure to play. Gives everyhing you would expect and more in a sandbox game, things to build, things to destroy, and many, many options. I mean that. This game is great for those who love astronomy and astrology (yes, they are different), and is yet still entertaining for someone who wants to blow things up.FEATURES:Early access, so you still have a chance to influence how the game develops, and may get special access to things later on in the development.Might be the best thing to do ever while listening to music or podcast or radio etc. Seriously, IDC if it is rap or classical music, does very well.PROS:Beautiful and well madeMany options, lives up to the sandbox titleFor anyone, and everyone. All can enjoy this titleCONS:Hard to call a game, more a tool/means of entertainment (aka not typical for steam)(some consider this a PRO)Confusing(even though it is great for people just wanting to have fun, it can confuse both with interface and astronomy)Dependant on you, this "software" (I suppose better than game), does not give you scenarios besides a few templates. You have to do everything to make something happen. (can take a lot of time)

Posted: December 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is beautiful, fun, and so well made. I feel bad for all of the people who wrote reviews saying they got bored with the Universe after only a few hours, it shows an immense lack of creativity. Yes, you can crash planets into each other, you can blow up the sun, you can crash stars together, and I can see how some people would get bored if that was all they ever did. Did I do some of those things when I first started playing? Yes, because it's fun and funny. You want to know what I did after that? I changed the orbit of Saturn's moons to draw them in closer, causing their orbit trails become bright, colorful rings as they mixed into the debris of Saturn's rings. For good measure I threw Russell's teapot into orbit tooI created a binary solar system from two Sirius B's, with Iapetus and Venus in orbit around one, and Mars and Dione in orbit around the other. I watched a simulated span of 27 days cause Iapetus and Dione to disintegrated and spiral outward into the blackness. I saw emptiness fill up with sparkling lights from the remnants of those moons. I watched Venus begin to heat up till it glowed brighter than the star it was orbiting, and Mars fill with fire leaving glowing streamers in the wake of it's orbit.There is so much you can do with this game, so many ways to create and destroy, infinite possibilities in the vastness of space, only bound by the limits of your imagination.

Posted: March 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I could never afford the telescope that would focus clearly on the rings of Saturn, or even focus on the bands of Jupiter. Happily this is the compilation of all those wonders of the solar system, and the galaxies beyond I have always hankered for.Chock full of data about real objects in space, truly immense distances and time scales traversed with the sweep of a mouse, so many questions I had not the wit to ask, have been answered in this armchair space explorer.Awesome, because it shows what is known to be out there. But also allows us to create models of the 'what if' kind, so injecting some creative fun into the serious baseness of astrophysics. Someone needs to suggest it to Chuck Lorre & Bill Prady for inclusion in the Big Bang Theory, those nerdy MIT guys would know how to really bang the rocks off this ultimate sandbox!

Posted: November 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I can't create a functional solar system yet but I can sure figure out a way to f**k it up by just clicking on things. Terrorism simulator 2015. 9/11 would be a universal terrorist again.Pros-You can blow planets up with ease, no need for silly nukes, warframes, or deathstars.-Cool presets which usually result in some sort of destruction, or can be modified to cause it with minimal effort.-See how many times you can f**k over the Earth and realize how fragile it is so you can't sleep at night.-Shouting ALLAHU AKBAR when blowing up the Earth is satisfying.-Black holes-Pretty colors when things blow up.-Did I mention destroying things.Cons-Can get a bit laggy at times (but thats probably just me putting an excessive amount of space things for no reason and my laptop cant handle it)-Get mad at the universe or god or whatever you want to believe in because you can't create a perfect solar system unless you use presets or are in fact god.-Makes you fear for your very existance.-A few bugs here and there as with any game but nothing gamebreaking, barely notice them.Overall I would definatly give this game a 10/10 at its current state. Get it if you like to see stuff in the universe blowing up.

Posted: March 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played the original Universe Sandbox many years ago, and was amazed by how well it was made, especially for a 2011 game! And this game leaves the first one in the dust. This game is amazing, ever wanted to launch the sun at Earth? Make Saturn into a rocky Earth-like planet with water? Go ahead. This game never fails to excite and entertain me with its endless possibilities.I'm very impressed by it's climate control and it's 3D lighting system for the continents, and how launching things at the Earth actually causes a crator to fill in with water, making it very realistic. I also like to freeze Earth over until it get's to -60 degrees and all the lights go out at night (they probably froze to death, or the worldwide power shut off because of the cold.) Thank you for making this absolutely stunning game!

Posted: March 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Didn't play this game for a long time yet, but I feel like it definitely deserves an upvote. Compared to the first title, this game is highly performant and full of details. It's very polished and works like a charm. Although I'm not a Master of Astrophysics, the physics seem very accurate and on point. With the large amount of content at hand, your possibilities are only bounded by your imagination. Despite it's "Early Access" status I haven't found any crucial bugs yet. No "Early Alpha Access Possibly 10 Years (Never Finish) Development" crap. You're buying a full game with (hopefully) more stuff to come. This game needs to be played. You're worth it.

Posted: November 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								First of all, this game is amazing. If you're a fan of space this is a must-have for you. It's incredible how detailed and full of amazing features this simulator is, how well made it is also, everything from the physics engine to the planet models to the way they would behave in an enviroment you can make all by yourself, how you can change anything about a cosmic object, it's speed,  it's mass, what elements it's composed of...What would happen to an Earth that is slightly tilted 5 more degrees inside of our Solar System? You can observe the changes in weather it would have because you can also see it get more snowy on some parts where it usually doesn't snow. It's details like that make me go "woah... I can LEARN so much from thiiiiis".This simulation game truly makes me happy. Space is awesome and this game makes you be part of it and even play god inside of it. I'm being serious, if you're a fan of space, get this game, you won't regret it.

Posted: December 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Universe Sandbox² is amazing, it is the best and one of the only space simulators avalable to the public. The graphics are brilliant (providing you dont have an old computer/laptop), the music is just relaxing and fits with the simulator and the experiance, of just sitting there amazed by what is possible is phenomonal. Best of all, it is incredibly accurate. All of which are attributes make it more realistic, as well as the choice of engene and the simulated physics. There are absolutely no improvements possible, other than engine updates. You should definitely buy it. If you havn't got much money, buy Unverse Sandbox, if you do have more money, buy Universe Sandbox² and if you can afford it, I would recomend that you buy both. If your'e going to give money to someone, make sure it is to people who work for it, to make everybody else happy. It is an experiance, that you can't forget. Good work guys! :)

Posted: May 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I only played for a little bit, before bed last night, but here are my thoughts.I play this entirely with the Vive, so I'm not sure how deep the simulation aspects are in the "Normal" version.As for Vive, it seems that your options are limited to spawning celestial bodies like stars, planets, and moons. You can launch them, or you can place them, and all bodies have gravity. If you place a planet near a sun, it will get sucked in and explode. Likewise, if you launch the planet around the sun, with enough velocity no less, it will make an orbit and continue on that course. Suns near suns are fun, do enough of them and you'll create a super nova that expands into a giant nebula. My framerate started to dip a bit, when I exploded a few dozen suns and made a massive nova or three. I'm using a GTX 980, for the record.I have yet to figure out how to make black holes or more complex systems, and I'm not sure if that's even possible yet. Here's hoping.What's here so far is pretty relaxed and simple, but it's also very engaging. If you're at all interested in astronomy, you'll be fascinated by Universe Sandbox 2. If you've played the first one, you'll know what to expect, and you'll be pleased with the extra work they've put into this one. If you're looking for progressive mechanics and stuff to hold your hand and show you how to do everything, maybe not. This title is less of a game, more like software. It's a true simulator, and it does what it intends to do very well.The music is also pretty nice. :PAll in all, I certainly recommend this title, especially if you're an HTC Vive user and you're looking for something to blow your mind.Here's hoping the development continues on this and we see even more wonders to immerse ourselves into.

								To say that this game is everything I wanted of it would severely undersell it. It's fabulously executed, and the soundscapes are especially lovely. Planets keep track of what they're made of, so you can try to terraform stuff, and it'll tell you how Earth-like your planet is, as well as how likely to support life it is. All around, it's a fabulous game.10/10 would try to terraform Mars and accidentally drop it into the sun again.

Posted: February 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I started simple- I like watching Solar Systems form for some reason, so I simulated it on a small scale. I spawned a random rocky planet, then spammed in about 50 different small moons, all of the same orbital path. They, of course, exploded catastrophically, causing a large shower of fragments to be sent off into space, and eventually left the one true moon- Orde, as well as a somewhat dense field of fragments. Then I turned to terraforming. I had finally got the planet to look good, but then a fair amount of the fragments of the satellite field crashed into both the host planet and Orde, leaving large craters in both. Eventually, the Planet cooled down, leaving Orde (3.3x Moon) entirely bathed in fire. Couldn't figure out how to put it out, so I thought making it bigger might help. Nope. Orde crashed into the Planet, causing another large explosion and a shower of fragments. Eventualy settled into what I called the Orde Pseudo Star, hurdling through the void. Set it to 0 Velocity, and started over. Things progressed, and I had a nice system going. Then Orde began to move. didn't notice, but then it ate the closest planet, and so I was like, what the heck, might as well blow everything up. Turned all the mass into hydrogen, which turned Orde into a star, and it ate everything. Turns out solar systems are a lot bigger than I thought. This is why I don't have nice things. I turn them into stars and then they consume everything else in existence. Gr8 m8 r8 8/8 Would consume universe accidentally again.

Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I absolutely love this game. I'll keep this review short: Want to blow up Washington DC because you know one way or another the USA is effed? Send a giant rock at it. Want to blow up Canada because they have it so good and your current country of living sucks, and you are jealous? Send a giant rock at it.Want to just end the Earth because you are sick of everything? A couple options: #1, Send Ceres, the Moon, or any hugely massive body at Earth. #2, Make the Sun go Supernova, (even though it is physically impossible in real life for the Sun to naturally go Supernova, for a multitude of reasons) and watch the earth vaporize.Want to mess with the orbits of planets in our solar system? Just send a new Jupiter careeening through the system at an impossible speed, and watch the chaos!Want to see what happens when a bowling ball hits the earth at many many times the speed of light? You can do that.And last but not least: Do you just want to marvel at the beauty of our solar system, watch planetary collisions, or see the Milky Way and Andromeda Galaxy collide in real time (it's really boring, but you can if you want)? These are just a few of the many many things you can do In Universe Sandbox ².I cannot recommend this game enough!

								This simulator has everything. You just can't get that satisfaction of destroying planets, its inhabitants, and entire star systems with the click of a mouse button anywhere else. All I have to say is that they managed to pull off quite an excellent game, can't wait when the other updates are released. Final Review:15/10 - Would over heat my CPU again11/10 "enough water"-IGN"Best Game EVER"-Galactus

Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I tried it for 3 hours 9/11/16. The text entry fields didn't work consistently. For example, in the Climate Lesson it highlights the Rotational Period box and prompts me to type "1d." Nothing changes in the selcted field for any keyboard entry, though on the fifth time restarting that lesson I was able to type "1." I had similar problems with the graphs and the time step (how fast the simulation runs). Exiting the game, one is prompted to provide feedback. That box consistently accepts text input, but it is not a large box and it overflows its interface rather than making a scrollbar. When it does so, both feedback fields become unresponsive and one has to start over. So I had about the same experience I could have had watching videos of the tutorials, though there I wouldn't have wasted my time fighting the interface for $25. I requested a refund because the reason I wanted it now was to show it to science teachers I supervise for their classes this school year.

								I really enjoyed this game. However I will admit that when I first got it I was bored of it after a couple hours or so of playing. As they continue to bring out updates, they are adding more and more interesting things to do in the game. Before purchasing, you need to realize that this is a simulation, not a story driven game, also it is in early access, it is not meant to be the game of the year. It is a little bit more expensive for what it's worth, but it is easy to see that time was put in to making this game and the developers want to deliver an amazing simulation experience of our universe, and I appreciate that. The graphics are beautiful and the physics of the game are astonishing. It is safe to say this game is out of this world ;). (Pun most definitely intended) I absolutely recommend purchasing this simulation and I look forward to future updates of the game.

Posted: October 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a Microsoft Developer & support person, an Apple anything you can think of, a retired IT Operations, Programming, Systems Management, etc. for Walmart, ARVEST Banks, Texas Commerce Bank, Washington Regional Hospital, & numerous other companies, an Independent IT Consultant, IRC Administrator, and general computer person going clear back to the old IBM S/360 days, I rarely ever have to buy software.  I made an exception for Universe Sandbox 2. It is downright the best piece of code to come out in a decade. I did Mechanical Engineering at University of Texas & University of Arkansas, Aero-Mechanical Engineering at University of Arizona, and amassed around 1000 credit hours in my long student career. Along the way, I took enough credit hours for minors in Physics (astrophysics and subatomic physics being my favorites), Math, & Computer Programming. I would love to see the commented code & underlying physics, math, and numerical solutions for this program. It does multi-body orbital mechanics so well and so fast it blows my mind. Actually, I suspect I know exactly how its doing it, but when there are hundreds of bodies involved, its simply amazing. For $25, this is a must have program. If you use your intuition and the included teaching (under Open), anybody can learn to blow up anything in the Universe, from galaxies down to minor planets, comets, etc., see Planet 9, and quite literally make the Universe your sandbox. Its amazingly simple to use, with quite intuitive solutions; make a guess & you will probably be right. And it makes an awesome scree saver, too! Get this app! Buy it! :-)

Posted: December 23, 2015
Early Access Review
Possibly the best sandbox game that I have ever playedFor those of you who don't know it, Universe Sandbox 2 is essentially an interstellar sandbox where you can create everything you want, ranging from planetoids and asteroids to black holes and hypergiant stars, and then put things in orbits - or launch said things at each other. When I first saw videos about this game - and its non-Steam predecessor, Universe Sandbox - I got a very general first impression: Explosions. Take a thing, add thing (at a collision course with a high velocity), get explosion. And from what I saw, the explosions were great, as were the collisions - especially in US2, the game I shall focus on. I was sold. I had to get it. And so I did.Of course I started with blowing things up. How could I resist? I started off with crashing Deimos into Earth, more precisely into the eastern US seaboard (thanks, Obama). I then proceeded to crash the Moon into the Pacific Ocean. Rest in peace, guys. But I didn't stop there. I threw what was left of Earth (a flaming ball, basically) into Jupiter. Then I threw Jupiter into the Sun. Then I threw the Sun into a bigger star, which also mumbo-jumbed the planetary orbits and sent Saturn, Neptune and Uranus into the deep unknown. I ended my destruction spree by crashing the largest star known to science into the second largest star known to science. The resulting supernova would have made Michael Bay ♥♥♥♥ his pants. And yet, I felt that something was missing. The destruction was fun, but it didn't feel like it had a purpose. So I left my pretty screwed-up solar systems behind and opened a new simulation. I added a Sun-like star into the centre, and then experimented a bit. I added a Mercury-ish planet which got pretty hot, a Jupiter-ish planet with many, many moons and an Earth with lots of water. The Mercury planet disappeared - it probably got destroyed by something that wasn't a moon, the Jupiter planet gobbled up its moons and all the water on Earth point 2 had all its water boiled off. So I tried again. I created a new solar system and did what I could to create functional orbits and planets with reasonable distances.What happened next was unexpected. As I finished setting up moons for my gas giant affectionately named Camillus after my crush, I looked at it's grand silhouette from the perspective of one of its natural satellites, decorated by the other orbiting moons. The sight filled me with awe. There are few games that can make me cry tears of awe, but Universe Sandbox 2 is a worthy candidate. This is not a joke.When you do what you can to destroy what can be destroyed, you feel a bit like a brutal god, and that is indeed very fun. But when you successfully create an Earth-like planet and watch its chances of life increase, when you watch the moons of a gas giant in orbit, when you gaze upon the mightiness of VY Canis Majoris, then you simply realize how amazing the universe is.And that is what this game succeeds at. It doesn't tell a complicated story, it doesn't give you a mission, but it gives you a beautiful understanding of our entire existence. And it does so beautifully. To make this look a bit more like an actual review, here's a paragraph on the things about this game that are good and bad. Good things? Very scientifically accurate (yes, I am a nerd), especially when it comes to physics. Great graphics, generally very beautiful when it comes to aesthetics. Very diverse when it comes to things you can do. Great randomization options for atmospheres, visuals, density and lots of other things. Oh, and all the other things I mentioned. Bad stuff? Only minor bugs, mostly related to sounds and mechanics. Could have some more minor objects like satellites, and more variation in asteroids. Oh, and I guess the black holes and ring dynamics are kinda screwed up at this stage. However, that is all which I consider bad about this game. And seeing as this is an Early Access game, I have full faith in the development team that they will sharpen the game to create a flawless experience.Essentially, this is the best sandbox i've ever played. Now if you'll excuse me, I have a star system to create (and hopefully not blow up).9.8/10

Early Access Review

You can change a lot of settings in different menus, although you might have to look things up for some of them with the amount of complicated physics involved (who would've guessed, in a game about space nonetheless). Posted: May 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I only played for a little bit, before bed last night, but here are my thoughts.I play this entirely with the Vive, so I'm not sure how deep the simulation aspects are in the "Normal" version.As for Vive, it seems that your options are limited to spawning celestial bodies like stars, planets, and moons. You can launch them, or you can place them, and all bodies have gravity. If you place a planet near a sun, it will get sucked in and explode. Likewise, if you launch the planet around the sun, with enough velocity no less, it will make an orbit and continue on that course. Suns near suns are fun, do enough of them and you'll create a super nova that expands into a giant nebula. My framerate started to dip a bit, when I exploded a few dozen suns and made a massive nova or three. I'm using a GTX 980, for the record.I have yet to figure out how to make black holes or more complex systems, and I'm not sure if that's even possible yet. Here's hoping.What's here so far is pretty relaxed and simple, but it's also very engaging. If you're at all interested in astronomy, you'll be fascinated by Universe Sandbox 2. If you've played the first one, you'll know what to expect, and you'll be pleased with the extra work they've put into this one. If you're looking for progressive mechanics and stuff to hold your hand and show you how to do everything, maybe not. This title is less of a game, more like software. It's a true simulator, and it does what it intends to do very well.The music is also pretty nice. :PAll in all, I certainly recommend this title, especially if you're an HTC Vive user and you're looking for something to blow your mind.Here's hoping the development continues on this and we see even more wonders to immerse ourselves into.

Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								As an early access game, (honestly, even if it were a full release game), this game takes the cake.I love the precise info you can get on planets, the general customizability, endless creative options, and all the physics. Pretty much whatever you want to do from messing around with black holes more massive than the Milky Way, to finely tuning your very own stellar systems, it's pretty darn fun.It could have some improvements, and some things seems slightly odd, but none are major, and it is still early access.One such oddity I've found is many objects moving several trillion times the speed of light, which seems very inaccurate. As for improvements, long/latitude lines could be better, with actual degree labels. Surface view looks a little odd because of the ground textures, but that probably doesn't matter too much. It would also be endlessly cool to actually walk around on the planets you make. A way to measure surface distances on planets and stars would likewise be very useful, and especially a tool that tells you the length of daylight at certain coordinates on your planet.TL;DR: Just buy it, it's awesome. Space + God Powers + Explosions = Win.

Also according to the theory of general relativity all the planets in the solar system are slowly moving inwards to the sun(to the center of gravity) so after so many of thousands of years the planets would go into the sun.

Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Absolutely love Universe Sandbox but the VR support needs work. The fly movement mechanic is awkward, there's no search function, and I don't seem to be able to set up solar systems as easily as I can in desktop. It's just a little less flexible. For example I don't know how to make a stable circular orbit, there only seems to be the lauch option which you can set to orbital velocity but you're still eyeballing the direction and position. Lastly, scaling seems unpredictable as to where I'm going to end up (usually too far away from where I wanted), I feel like scale (and possibly locomotion) could benefit from a smartphone style "pinch" and "pull" mechanic. Perhaps holding the right grip buttons move space, the left grips adjust time and using both grips scales space.Definitely recommend for desktop use but would really love to see some better VR support.

Posted: May 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I only played for a little bit, before bed last night, but here are my thoughts.I play this entirely with the Vive, so I'm not sure how deep the simulation aspects are in the "Normal" version.As for Vive, it seems that your options are limited to spawning celestial bodies like stars, planets, and moons. You can launch them, or you can place them, and all bodies have gravity. If you place a planet near a sun, it will get sucked in and explode. Likewise, if you launch the planet around the sun, with enough velocity no less, it will make an orbit and continue on that course. Suns near suns are fun, do enough of them and you'll create a super nova that expands into a giant nebula. My framerate started to dip a bit, when I exploded a few dozen suns and made a massive nova or three. I'm using a GTX 980, for the record.I have yet to figure out how to make black holes or more complex systems, and I'm not sure if that's even possible yet. Here's hoping.What's here so far is pretty relaxed and simple, but it's also very engaging. If you're at all interested in astronomy, you'll be fascinated by Universe Sandbox 2. If you've played the first one, you'll know what to expect, and you'll be pleased with the extra work they've put into this one. If you're looking for progressive mechanics and stuff to hold your hand and show you how to do everything, maybe not. This title is less of a game, more like software. It's a true simulator, and it does what it intends to do very well.The music is also pretty nice. :PAll in all, I certainly recommend this title, especially if you're an HTC Vive user and you're looking for something to blow your mind.Here's hoping the development continues on this and we see even more wonders to immerse ourselves into.

								Great simulation and very educational. If you`re interested in astronomy in any way then this will appeal to you. Posted: May 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								To say that this game is everything I wanted of it would severely undersell it. It's fabulously executed, and the soundscapes are especially lovely. Collisions are dramatic and destructive, which is pretty fun. You can view your creation from the surface of any body involved, which has led me to some truly lovely views. Planets keep track of what they're made of, so you can try to terraform stuff, and it'll tell you how Earth-like your planet is, as well as how likely to support life it is. All around, it's a fabulous game.10/10 would try to terraform Mars and accidentally drop it into the sun again.

Posted: May 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I only played for a little bit, before bed last night, but here are my thoughts.I play this entirely with the Vive, so I'm not sure how deep the simulation aspects are in the "Normal" version.As for Vive, it seems that your options are limited to spawning celestial bodies like stars, planets, and moons. You can launch them, or you can place them, and all bodies have gravity. If you place a planet near a sun, it will get sucked in and explode. Likewise, if you launch the planet around the sun, with enough velocity no less, it will make an orbit and continue on that course. Suns near suns are fun, do enough of them and you'll create a super nova that expands into a giant nebula. My framerate started to dip a bit, when I exploded a few dozen suns and made a massive nova or three. I'm using a GTX 980, for the record.I have yet to figure out how to make black holes or more complex systems, and I'm not sure if that's even possible yet. Here's hoping.What's here so far is pretty relaxed and simple, but it's also very engaging. If you're at all interested in astronomy, you'll be fascinated by Universe Sandbox 2. If you've played the first one, you'll know what to expect, and you'll be pleased with the extra work they've put into this one. If you're looking for progressive mechanics and stuff to hold your hand and show you how to do everything, maybe not. This title is less of a game, more like software. It's a true simulator, and it does what it intends to do very well.The music is also pretty nice. :PAll in all, I certainly recommend this title, especially if you're an HTC Vive user and you're looking for something to blow your mind.Here's hoping the development continues on this and we see even more wonders to immerse ourselves into.

Posted: April 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Destroying humanity as we know it is great.For a few hours at least. Once destroying humanity gets boring, you can start fiddling with the other planets in the galaxy and learn that life in our solar system is like walking on a tightrope, one piece of the rope breaks, and everything goes hurling into nothingness. You can see our world, our solar system, our galaxy like never before with this amazing game.Outside of our galaxy, you can make your own custom body of planets, suns, whatever you feel like. Heck, you could have a black hole for a sun if you felt like it. You can build (and destroy) anything you feel like. If you don't feel like building yourself, there are hundreds of preset levels, my personal favorite being the galaxy colliding level.The music is beatiful, and calming as you explore the infinite blackness of space.The graphics wouldn't really be a problem, even if they were bad, but the visual experience in this game is breathtaking.Should you buy this game? Well, it's not exactly "fun". If you like adventure and shooter games and are in it for the challenge and fun, then no. But if you like exploring the galaxy or calmly watch as planets soar by, then yes. I absoloutely love this game. It is, in my opinion, it is well worth buying.10/10, would cry at the beauty and fragileness of the galaxy again.

Posted: March 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								You are a God. The God. The Ruler and Controller of the entire universe. Create Planets, destroy them, do whatever you like. The possibilities are virtually endless in this game. You can make your own universes and toy with space and time however you want. Make planets bigger, spawn/drop in/create existing planets, suns, black holes, etc. and manipulate them to your will. Make them bigger, smaller, denser, have more mass, anything. However, this game doesn't come without it's disadvantages.You need to have some standing and/or existing knowledge beforehand or read up a little on gravity, relativity, etc. or you might get a little frustrated as your planets might not do exactly what you want, and may just end up colliding into each other, and go full on supernova. But, if that's exactly what you want and you don't care, GREAT! Then this is the game for you. You will absolutely love this game, even with it's price.

Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								I tried it for 3 hours 9/11/16. The text entry fields didn't work consistently. For example, in the Climate Lesson it highlights the Rotational Period box and prompts me to type "1d." Nothing changes in the selcted field for any keyboard entry, though on the fifth time restarting that lesson I was able to type "1." I had similar problems with the graphs and the time step (how fast the simulation runs). Exiting the game, one is prompted to provide feedback. That box consistently accepts text input, but it is not a large box and it overflows its interface rather than making a scrollbar. When it does so, both feedback fields become unresponsive and one has to start over. So I had about the same experience I could have had watching videos of the tutorials, though there I wouldn't have wasted my time fighting the interface for $25. I requested a refund because the reason I wanted it now was to show it to science teachers I supervise for their classes this school year.

Posted: July 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								This simulator has everything. You just can't get that satisfaction of destroying planets, its inhabitants, and entire star systems with the click of a mouse button anywhere else. The physics engine is surreal, the visuals and seeing time and space unfold in front your very eyes in your cataclysmic simulations is just magnificent. The CPU usage is quite the odyssey, lets just say I am fortunate enough that my PC did not burst into a hyper nova after trying to run a simulation  with over 5000 moons orbiting Earth. All I have to say is that they managed to pull off quite an excellent game, can't wait when the other updates are released. Final Review:15/10 - Would over heat my CPU again11/10 "enough water"-IGN"Best Game EVER"-Galactus

Posted: July 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								So far, I enjoy this a lot.  Some knowledge of orbital mechanics and how large scale physics works is helpful in playing this game and getting the most out of the simulation.  It is not required, though.  You can always learn just by playing the game.  There is no goal with this game, it's just you, you're thoughts and whatever you can dream up, and frankly I love it.  It's so very relaxing after a long day, it's so very satisfying to change the way a planet works, and actually watch as your changes reflect on the surface and statistics of that planet, moon or star.  If you're interested in space or science, or you're looking to learn and teach yourself about them, I recommend this game

								It is a unique tool to understand the workings of the cosmos. And now, it looks even better. I really like it. Posted: March 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I recommend this title but know this.First off this is not really a game in my opinion. It is the definition of sandbox. There are no goals or end game. Your enjoyment will be completely dictated by the following1. Your imagination2. Your interest in the science of AstronomyIf you don't feel you have these qualities then it's likely that after 20-30 minutes you'll just find your self continously throwing planets and stars at one another. While this can be fun one can only blow up the Earth so many times until it gets boring. This is the type of sandbox that requires you to think "What if..." and then set up the scenario. The fun, for me, is in observing how bodies interact with one another. Really getting a sense of how everything in the universe is in motion at all times. Visually seeing how mass and gravity are intrinsicly tied to one another is very interesting to me. There are so many paramaters to tinker with it can be overwhelming but very rewarding if one spends the time experimenting.Experimenting is really what this sandbox is all about.Don't expect a manual or path to follow. The tutorial only gives you some basic ideas of what can be done, and as of this review is still partly bugged.Do expect a great learning experience and cool physical simulations that can inspire one to think about the scale of the universe and just how small we are.

								This game is amazing.Not only are the team always active and helpful, they also answer to negative comments to get feedback!WHAT OTHER TEAM DOES THAT!?!?!?!?!? (Don't answer that, I know there is probably others)Not only is it a fabulous team, the game itself is far beyond what I would expect for an early access game. It is very innovative and I can't wait until it is done!However, I have some negatives for it. For instance, being able to create your own planets (I am not sure if this is in yet) or being able to edit the colors and other things related to more customization. I am also confused on the controls using a gamepad (which I hardly use for this game) but it could be useful for people who prefer controllers.Other than that, I don't know what else to say so far, but I may update this later. Posted: January 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Really, it's just astonishing: not only to see such a beautiful, intricate, and basically FANTASTIC rendering of humanity's current working understanding of the cosmos, but to be able to run it on your computer at home (and cause all sorts of ellaborate, crazy mayhem, on all kinds of time scales...)... I mean, just "WOW." ... It just stuns me that such a beautiful rendering of our understanding of the cosmos can be purchased for 25 bucks... It's got the whole frigging universe in there just as a starting point... you get a majestic sense of time and space... its chaos, scale, symmetry, mysteries, marvels, phenomenon... and you can see it either as the vast and endless expanses of oblivion, or as the comically small billiard-table encapsulation of our water-droplet of existence... Either way, it's frigging awesome when you start making inconcievably humongous alterations or adjustments by say, distorting the orbits of planets by spawning humongous stars and then making them explode... (my personal fave, though, is simply being able to see the speed of light from our sun, rendered at scale... before exploding the sun and destroying all life as we know it, hahahha!). Super Highly recommended.
